SENT.plain: P53 is a tumour suppressor gene, located in the short arm of chromosome 17, which encodes for a nuclear protein involved in the control of cellular growth, regulating the entry of the cell into the S-phase
P53 mutations have been identified in a progressively increasing number of human malignancies
Nuclear p53 protein is usually present in non-tumour cells in minute concentrations, due to its short half-life

In contrast, tumours with p53 mRNA mutations show a higher nuclear protein concentration, detectable by immunohistological techniques, due to stabilization by complexing with other proteins such as heat-shock protein or wild-type p53 protein

Levels of nuclear p53 protein detected by immunohistochemistry with the monoclonal antibody PAb 1801 were measured with the aid of an image analysis system in 83 non-Hodgkin's lymphomas (NHLs) and 13 cases of Hodgkin's disease, as well as in 14 cases of normal thymus, reactive tonsils, and lymphadenitis
High levels of p53 protein (greater than 5 per cent of the cells) were present only in high-grade lymphomas (in the proportion 13/55), with a peak incidence in Burkitt's lymphoma (5/8 cases)

Lower levels (less than 5 per cent) of p53 protein were detected in low-grade B- and T-cell lymphomas, as well as in most of the cases of Hodgkin's disease, where p53 protein was selectively present in Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells
In 5/14 reactive tonsils or lymph nodes, occasional p53-positive cells were identified
These results suggest a relationship between levels of p53 protein and the aggressiveness of NHL.(ABSTRACT TRUNCATED AT 250 WORDS)
